metadata.case_name: Writ Petition No. 467 of 1972 (Petitioner v. State of Gujarat)

facts.text: Petitioner owns 9559 square yards of land situate in District Bulsar, sub-district and Taluka Navsari, village Kohilpore.

Petitioner intends to sell the said land but is unable to do so because of the prohibition of alienation imposed under the Gujarat Vacant Lands in Urban Areas Prohibition of Alienation Act, 1972 (Gujarat Act No. 12 of 1972).
Proclamation of Emergency is in operation under Article 358 of the Constitution, suspending fundamental rights under Article 19.

The Act is a temporary measure originally to remain in force for one year, extended from time to time to enable passage of Urban Property Ceilings Act; prohibition of alienation is preparatory for distribution of material resources.
Section 2 of the Act embodies declaration for giving effect to policy towards securing principles in clauses (b) and (c) of Article 39.
Preamble: Act to prohibit alienation of certain vacant lands in urban areas to prevent concentration of wealth and distribute material resources for common good.
Urban area defined in section 3(i): areas in City or municipal borough, vicinity up to 16 km as notified, or other areas declared urban due to projects.

Vacant land defined in section 3(j): land in urban area, agricultural or non-agricultural, other than land on which building constructed or being constructed per law, and appurtenant land to minimum extent.
Compact block defined in section 3(d): block of vacant land exceeding 1000 sq m, owned by one or more, or contiguous parts by family unit, whether divided by private road etc.

Section 4(1): Prohibits alienation of vacant land on/after appointed day by sale, gift etc., partition, trust; null and void if contravened. Proviso: excludes one plot <=1000 sq m not part of compact block.
Section 6: Act does not apply to transfers by/to State/Central Govt, local authority, Govt company, Govt corporation, approved cooperative house building societies for weaker sections.
Section 7(1): State Govt may exempt area/alienation for reasons recorded.
Section 7(2): State Govt may exempt to avoid hardship.
Section 7(3): Collector may exempt for educational, scientific, industrial, commercial or prescribed purposes.
Notifications issued fixing distances up to 16 km for big cities like Ahmedabad, Baroda, lesser for small boroughs.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Act violates Article 14 by denying equal protection of law.
Whether Article 31C saves the Act as relatable to Article 39(b) and (c).

petitioner_arguments.text: Limit of prohibition same irrespective of situation and value of vacant land, putting unequals as equals.
Act does not apply to building lands; building areas left out.
Discrimination between permissible limit of alienation based on irrational consideration of area forming part of compact block or not.
No rational basis for not applying Act to alienation in favour of State Govt, Central Govt, local authorities, Govt companies, corporations, cooperative house building societies.
No guideline provided in section 7 for exercise of power of exemption.
Act not directly relatable to object of Article 39(b) and (c), so Article 31C cannot protect it.

respondent_arguments.text: None of the points urged by petitioner has substance; no violation of Article 14.

court_reasoning.text: No need to take recourse to Article 31C as Act does not infringe Article 14.
When limit of distance outside city/town differs, not feasible to fix permissible area by value; excluding compact block prevents manipulations by family units.
Excluding building lands reasonable as object is to prevent alienation of vacant lands.
Exemptions for transfers to Govt etc. advance object of Act by aiding distribution and preventing concentration of wealth.
Guidelines for exemptions: reasons recorded for s7(1), hardship for s7(2), specific purposes for s7(3) as prescribed; supervised by legislature and appeal.
Classifications reasonable with clear nexus to object; neither puts unequals as equals nor discriminates between equals.

holdings.text: The Act does not infringe equal protection under Article 14; classifications reasonable and have nexus with object.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Act challenged for violating Arts 14 and 19; Art 19 suspended; Art 31C invoked but not needed.

statutes_cited.name: Gujarat Vacant Lands in Urban Areas (Prohibition of Alienation) Act, 1972
sections: Section 3 (clauses b, c, d, dd, e, i, j)
statutes_cited.relevance: Impugned Act; provisions on prohibition, definitions, exemptions analyzed for Art 14 challenge.

statutes_cited.name: Companies Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines Government Company for exemption under s6.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Town Planning Act, 1954
statutes_cited.relevance: Relevant for appurtenant land to buildings.

outcome.summary: Writ petition challenging constitutional validity of the Gujarat Vacant Lands in Urban Areas (Prohibition of Alienation) Act, 1972 under Articles 14 and 19 dismissed as Act does not violate Article 14 and Article 19 rights suspended.

key_quotes.text: "In our opinion it is not necessary in this case to take recourse to Article 31C for upholding the constitutional validity of the Act as it does not infringe the equal protection of law guaranteed under Article 14."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Classifications are all reasonable and there is a clear nexus between the object of the act and the classifications."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The object of the Act is to prohibit alienation of the vacant lands so that ultimately the ownership and control of the material resources of the Community may be so distributed as best to sub-serve the common good."
key_quotes.speaker: court
